qas.question: Was there a period when child labour was essential?
Was there a great need for childhood education in a pre-industrial society?

answers.text: little need for children to attend school

qas.question: Who taught the skills needed for the children to work?
Were peopel in pre-industrial societies considered to have long or short lifespans?

context: The work of children was important in <a0_0>pre-industrial societies<a0_0/>, as children needed to provide their labour for their survival and that of their group. Pre-industrial societies were characterised by low productivity and <a3_0>short life expectancy<a3_0/>, preventing children from participating in productive work would be more harmful to their welfare and that of their group in the long run. In pre-industrial societies, there was <a1_0>little need for children to attend school<a1_0/>. This is especially the case in non literate societies. Most pre-industrial skill and knowledge were amenable to being passed down through direct mentoring or apprenticing by <a2_0>competent adults<a2_0/>.
